head.title: Sub Tragedy Reveals a New Russia

hedline.hl1: Sub Tragedy Reveals a New Russia

abstract.p: Steven E F Brown disputes August 23 editorial which criticized Russian government for slow and inadequate response to sinking of submarine Kursk

block.p: In ''The Kursk and the Kremlin'' (editorial, Aug. 23), you criticize Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, for not immediately going to the rescue site after the nuclear submarine Kursk sank. But Mr. Putin was right to stay away.

In ''The Kursk and the Kremlin'' (editorial, Aug. 23), you criticize Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, for not immediately going to the rescue site after the nuclear submarine Kursk sank. But Mr. Putin was right to stay away.

After the 1989 earthquake in San Francisco, I worked as a volunteer on the collapsed Cypress Freeway in Oakland, and I saw how disruptive the visits of politicians could be when rescue workers and supervisors were diverted from their primary tasks to cater to V.I.P.'s.

Mr. Putin's arrival with a train of hangers-on would have created greater chaos and inefficiency as people scrambled to accommodate high-level visitors with tours, briefings and security arrangements. It is better in such an event to lead from afar and let your people on the scene do their work.
STEVEN E. F. BROWN San Leandro, Calif., Aug. 23, 2000
